Community Hub
Into the Stars
Take the role of Captain in this Space Survival Simulation as you explore a massive star system in search of a new home for humanity. Outfit your ship, hand pick your crew and set off on a journey through an open-world where you must scavenge resources, shelter civilians and outrun a hostile alien force.
User reviews: Mixed (179 reviews) - 63% of the 179 user reviews for this game are positive.
Release Date: Jul 9, 2015

Title: Into the Stars
Genre: Indie , Simulation , Strategy , Early Access
Developer: Fugitive Games
Publisher: Iceberg Interactive
Release Date: Jul 9, 2015

Visit the website View the manual View the manual View update history Read related news View discussions Find Community Groups

Early Access Game

Get instant access and start playing; get involved with this game as it develops.

Note: This Early Access game is not complete and may or may not change further. If you are not excited to play this game in its current state, then you should wait to see if the game progresses further in development. Learn more

What the developers have to say:

Why Early Access?

“The world of Into the Stars is quite large, meaning that populating it and experimenting with every gameplay variable is very time intensive for our small team. We realized that the best way to continue fleshing out our star system while tuning for a balanced experience was to open the game up to our Kickstarter backers and the Early Access community. With your feedback and a little more time we’ll be able to deliver the quality game you all deserve.”

Approximately how long will this game be in Early Access?

“ Release Target: Early Q1 2016

Putting an exact time stamp on this phase of development is difficult because we’ll be dividing our efforts between planned content creation and reacting to community feedback. All of this will be shaped by our exacting standards, but our intention is to spend as little time as required in Early Access, which we anticipate to be a couple of months. Given the current state of the game we feel this is more than achievable.”

How is the full version planned to differ from the Early Access version?

“Our goal in Early Access is to flesh out and polish the world of Into the Stars while adding the following:

- Varied difficulty settings for a number of play styles
- Enhancements to existing gameplay systems
- Text localization for a number of languages
- Additional Steam Features
- Mac support

You can see our full Development Roadmap here:
https://trello.com/b/47OqxpnV/into-the-stars-public-roadmap ”

What is the current state of the Early Access version?

“The game is currently in BETA and contains dozens of hours of replay-focused gameplay featuring 4 Alien Races, over 100 events, countless planets to explore and a complete soundtrack from Jack Wall.”

Will the game be priced differently during and after Early Access?

“Yes. Into the Stars will have a reduced price point during Early Access and will likely see a price increase of 25% at launch.”

How are you planning on involving the Community in your development process?

“Working closely with the community to craft the experience is at the core of this decision. Our intention is to take community feedback from our forums and social media, distill it down to priorities and factor it all in as we refine the game. We’ll be watching those areas vigilantly and creating an open dialogue with all those who wish to participate in the process.”
Read more

About This Game

We’ve been under attack for 10 years now. Every 6 months the Skorn arrive, set on destroying our planet, and now few of us remain to defend what’s left. The massive Ark ships we’ve built in hopes of escaping them have all gone, save one. You must take the role of Captain of our final vessel, the Ark 13, and guide a hand-picked, but inexperienced crew on a journey fraught with intrigue and danger. The fate of the Endurance Coalition is uncertain and you could well be our last hope. How will you fare once you set out Into the Stars?

Into the Stars is an open-world Space Survival Simulation built in Unreal Engine 4, featuring an original score from Jack Wall.

Take the role of Captain as you explore a massive star system in search of a new home for humanity. Outfit your ship, hand pick your crew and set off on a journey where you must scavenge resources, shelter civilians and either outrun, or outgun a hostile alien force, in order to survive.

Key Features

  • Complete Control: Take command of your hand-picked, but inexperienced crew, and guide them through a star system packed with mystery and danger.
  • Explore a Massive Star System: You have the freedom to set your course for salvation, but no approach is free from peril. Each of the 90 zones in this system present unique opportunities, along with challenges, and only you can find the path to success.
  • Challenging volley-based Combat: A number of foes, who are unwilling to negotiate, await you on this voyage. That's why your ship is equipped with weapon systems that speak for the human race, in a language everyone can understand. Choose your target points, battle stations and crew wisely, if you want to survive numerous alien encounters.
  • Music by Jack Wall: Driven by an original score from the legendary composer behind the music for Mass Effect, Call of Duty and Lost Planet.
  • Replayability: Every decision you make as Captain, and every randomly generated obstacle the crew encounters, can affect the outcome of a mission, creating a different experience, every time you play.
READ MORE

System Requirements

    Minimum:
    • OS: Windows 7 64-bit Service Pack 1
    • Processor: 2.5 GHz or faster Intel or AMD processor
    • Memory: 4 GB RAM
    • Graphics: NVIDIA GeForce 470 GTX or AMD Radeon 6870 HD series card or higher
    • DirectX: Version 11
    • Hard Drive: 2 GB available space
    • Additional Notes: Only Standard 16:10 & 16:9 Screen Resolutions are supported at this time.
    Recommended:
    • OS: Windows 8.1
    • Processor: Quad-core Intel or AMD processor
    • Memory: 8 GB RAM
    • Graphics: DX11 Compatible Video Card
    • DirectX: Version 11
    • Hard Drive: 2 GB available space
    • Additional Notes: Only Standard 16:10 & 16:9 Screen Resolutions are supported at this time.
READ MORE

digitalmaleficus

24.4 hrs on record
Posted: October 15
Early Access Review
Okay now it's been awhile since I've written a review (previously under the name The Gamer Gourmet) so bare with me.

Now this game has a bit of history with me. I was one of the unfortunate ones who were getting stuck behind the Nebraska error. After some attempts I requested a refund. Then an update came out. Loving what I had been seeing, I chanced getting it again. Still prevented by the error :(.

Some time passed and a work-around came about involving an update to WMSIE. Viola it worked!!

I was beyond jazzed because everything I read, saw, heard was exactly the game I felt I needed to stave off the fiend until No Mans Sky comes out. time for the nitty gritty.

The game is as described. A combination of Bridge Commander, FTL, and several other space born titles. At first it can feel over whelming. LOTS of details.

"Like being on a date with a Librarian, who also is chocolate for the eyes"

The setup is a big deal as if effects the rest of your ability to survive in the vastness of space. Crew finding is relatively easy, able to sort them by highest rating in their fields and found the crew set up the easiest, although not quite sure of the necessity of a toughness trait, often ignoring it to double up on engineers.

The hardest (or I should say toughest choice) was the modules. While the urge to get modules that use the same resources, you will discover certain planets can only be mined for specific ones...in other words, your Ark maybe based around a lot of CO2 usage but find a planet that contains none.

This is usually the first error I can see made during the first attempt at playing

The difficulties however are easily tempered through multiple plays....but still can seem overwhelming at first.

Once past the multiple set up screens you are greeted with a beautiful scenery of planets, asteroids, suns and all sorts of anomalies. The feeling of being able to go anywhere is amazing. The controls are simple, up down left right roll.

The game is a graphical beast for sure. The suns have solar flares, the planets have rings of asteroids, there's even half cracked destroyed planets frozen in time.

Exploring and taking int eh sights is an easy thing to get lost in immediately in this game. The urge to push on is apparent right off the bat, JUST to see more space related eye candy.

But then comes the first 'break' from this joy. The constant pursuit by the main enemy race in the game. The Skorn. Now I understand the desire to have this element. It gives a constant urgency to keep mushing on. It did however leave me annoyed often when trying to explore a new area, just to find I am getting tracked before even finding anything. BUT its a minor issue and like I said, keeps the constant feeling of 'keep on pushing on', which does force a positive need to progress forward whether u want to or not.

The space battles are my biggest frown. Often the same battle consisting of 1-3 enemy ships which pretty much may vary in design, but still consist of the same. Now I haven't indulged the game 100% so I am unsure if any other enemy but the Skorn fight you, but have played enough to be able to say I'm pretty sure you don't. This leaves a bitter lack of creativity int he battles. You get into a battle, try to disable a ships weapons, finish them off repeat if more ships. Often battles being purely determined on the ability to be lucky, and your shots come in contact with their targets. However once 'experienced' these battles often become routine, and make little impact other than slowing you down some OR rarely sometimes the rewards from such giving a much needed resource boost. At first, a nice mechanic to the game but ultimately becoming a 'sigh' moment.

This would be, as the developer, my primary focus when it comes to altering, upgrading, altering the game. More alien vessels to combat, more options in combat, howabout the simple ability to flee would be nice sometimes, even a boarding ability. Often the battles fall on the same 3 basic principles. Phasers, torpedoes, shields. It becomes paper rock scissor type combat. It is attempted to be deeper through a color coordinated battle scheme (red shields absorb red weapons etc) but this falls kinda flat and small enhancement to a drab combat system. It needs to be deeper, enhanced someway, perhaps some form of mini-game to determine effectiveness, accuracy, rate of fire etc. It simply needs to be more in depth especially being 1/3 of the games entertainment.

Now aside form combat the games meat and potatoes come from surviving. Managing resources, and finding the methods to go from one end to the other in the galaxy. The sites again, are amazing. The aura, and feel of different parts and lighting effects give a sensed of dream like state, as you approach a sector of random marvel.

however with the grandness that comes with it, multiple plays lead to a 'almost cramped feeling'> the galaxy is universal, each play has the same layout. While it has TONS of sights, playing many play through's makes even this large galaxy seem small. BUT even so, the sights and number of anomalies leave more to discover even after my 15th play.

The galaxy is large and the limitations of randomness, are only enhanced by an obvious attention to detail. Random alien vessels litter the galaxy but often only provide a lackluster trading opportunity. This was quite disappointing as I was hoping to combat some of the other vessels and they end up being a minor 'mix' in the formula. Forgettable at worse, minor help at best. It would be nice if the event offered more, like a side mission or something.

Planetary exploration is descent distraction in the game. Especially when fighting to survive with moments when low on resources, like those that provide food or air, or fuel. Most the time these visits to planets involve drilling for resources which is based around a mini game of guiding a 2d drill into the ground going over the resource squares you need. A simple mechanic but often entertaining as when in a hurry find yourself eager to go fast but with haste often find yourself hitting the 'bad squares' that stop the drilling altogether. This can be frustrating when dealing with an impending patrol and a dire need for fuel/air/food necessity. BUT however is tempered with the simple mechanic the more u drill the easier the drilling becomes...with more risk comes greater reward. And after a few ship upgrades the battles become relatively easy so the desire to suck as much resources is an often tease....stockpile and fight, or get a quick fix and flee.....

Now throughout your travels you will often have ship born emergencies. Stuff from a random viral outbreak, to space raccoon's making a mess. These missions are relatively handled the same way. Assign a crew member to it, depending their level in the particular skill required depends on the rate they finish the objective. A past time event usually only causing issues when finding yourself with many on board ship issues at once and suddenly being attacked as each device needs a crew member to work (phasers, shields, missiles, medical). Not really a major feature but does keep you micro managing things.

For the price the game is worth it. There's many more features but not enough space to list them. You love space games, you will love this game. With its flaws, still is a gem that needs some more polish!

Early Access Review
Finally a Space Game where you are the captain AND the pilot.
I have right off the bat that the graphics are AMAZING! The controls are smooth and not hard to learn at all. The Strategy of choosing the right modules and keeping on your toes about keeping your ship moving and on the watch for aliens out to kill you is great. Puts you on the edge.
I recommend this game 100%

Posted: October 12
Early Access Review
*early acces review and i got this copy for free after playing it at Firstlook*

While the battle may be a bit bland, traveling around is a joy,seeing as the game has a beautiful world.
But there it ends a bit, the the UI consists mostly of the standard Unity buttons and basic functionality like drag and drop are missing.
They can improve the UI a lot more and make encounters more engaging, but they are on the right way.

But at the end of the day the game grips me and i want to play a bit more.

PS: the devs are great guys
